title: Just curious, why does Lee Sin need %HP damage when his key targets are squishies, not tanks?
body: I mean my understanding of these things is that %HP damage is meant to either allow damage dealers to shred tanks, or allow tanks to retan meaningful damage while building primarily defense. But Lee is neither of those. He targets squishies and has plenty of meaningful damage from high AD ratios. So why does he need %HP damage?

His Q has 8% missing health bonus damage, and his ultimate has additional 12/15/18% BONUS health damage scaling.

I do agree that Lee Sin is typically used more or less as a duelist style champion early on in the game, up until about level 11 unless you are way ahead, the missing health Q damage is really good for finishing off low-health targets and increases his capabilities in the jungle as he gains a lot of damage after you smite a camp and then use your second Q active "Resonating Strike" to finish off said camp.

His ultimate having bonus health scaling is a weird concept to me knowing that his most priority targets are usually carries and are squishy, most of which will nearly never build extra health items as a priority short of maybe Rylais, Liandry's, or Rod of Ages on AP mages, or a Black Cleaver, Triforce on AD assassins/fighters that are not tanks.  If that is the case, and someone like a Cassioepeia builds a Rylai's and Liandry's, that's 700 bonus health from items, and Lee Sin's ultimate would be doing roughly 120 bonus damage at Rank 3.  So I do agree that the ultimate bonus health scaling is a little weird for his main purpose.  His ultimate might be helpful for diving tanks 2v1 or for top lane ganks and such, but the scaling doesn't really benefit him anywhere else particularly significantly like you mentioned.  

This whole post may seem like a bit of a roundabout essay, but the TL;DR is basically, the Q scaling is really good for him in ganks and in the jungle, and his ult scaling is a little odd, especially with the AD ratios that he already has.

The majority of people in this thread (including the OP) don't even understand how the %health damage on Lee's ult even works, and yet they still manage to have an opinion on it. Impressive. It literally only does the %health damage if you kick 1 enemy into another, only does the extra damage to the champion hit by whoever Lee kicked, and the damage scales off the bonus HP of the target Mundo kicked. If Lee kicks a Mundo with 2000 bonus health, any targets Mundo collides with will take an extra 360 damage. Mundo himself will not take this damage. 

TL;DR Getting hit by huge flying tanks fucking hurts. How this wasn't in the game ago is a mystery to me.

If I'm not mistaken, it's there such that he can target tanks when you can't target squishies. 

While Lee Sin does have the mobility to make sure that this is never the case, what happens when that isn't the case? What if the Lee Sin player physically cannot utilize his incredible mobility to get to the enemy squishies and kick them into your team?

This change allows less skilled Lee Sin players to be able to kick tanks into the enemy squishies' face for engage or kick the enemy tanks away from your squishies' for peel rather than kick the enemy team's squishies to kill them as compensation for not being a good Lee Sin player.

This is a dangerous way of thinking.

What if you're {{champion:74}} and you can't get your turrets down? You get your ass kicked.
What if you're {{champion:75}} and can't get your stacks? You get your ass kicked.
What if you're {{champion:106}} and you keep getting kited? You get your ass kicked.
What if you're {{champion:64}} and you can't target a squishy? You target a tank instead.

You see the difference there? With a lot of champs, if they fail at a key part of their playstyle, they have no plan B. That's what keeps them balanced and gives them counterplay. You kill Donger's turrets, he's much less of a threat. You stop Nasus from farming, you're gonna keep him weak. You kite just about any juggernaut, they're a sad panda. This is true for the vast majority of champs.

Lee just doesn't work that way. He's got the tools to deal with just about anything you throw at him. He's always got a plan B for when you foil plan A. That's why people really don't respond well to his kit; just when you think you've countered him or outplayed him, he's got some way of negating it. If a tank goes in to intercept him from bursting down a squishy, Lee can opt to just ult the tank back into the squishy. And then he ward hops away from any further retaliation, because outplaying Lee is more than a two man job at times.
